questions.text: Arrange the following in the sequence in which they occur, after the 'p wave' in ECG: A- 'a' wave B- 1st heart sound C- Rapid filling of ventricles D- 't' wave
Which of the following factors is not necessary for determining creatinine clearance?

options.label: D
options.text: The volume of serum passing through the kidney in 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: D. The volume of serum passing through the kidney in 24 hours
questions.explanation:
Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing?

options.label: B
options.text: Vagal output to cardiac fibers increase

questions.correct_answer: A. Decrease in firing from baroreceptor
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Mechanism
  • Baroreceptors in carotid sinus and aortic arch detect BP changes
  • Increased BP stretches receptors, sending signals to medulla via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves
  • Medulla inhibits vasoconstrictor center and stimulates vagal parasympathetic center (Option B ruled out)
  • It is a rapid negative feedback loop in which an elevated blood pressure causes the heart rate to decrease. Decreased blood pressure decreases baroreflex activation and causes heart rate to increase and to restore blood pressure levels. (Option A)

Actions
  • Vasodilation of blood vessels
  • Decreased heart rate and contraction strength (Option D ruled out)
  • Reduced BP due to lower peripheral resistance and cardiac output

Importance
  • Maintains BP stability during activities like standing
  • Fastest acting
  • Tends to reset within 1-2 days for long-term regulation

What will be the most likely associated condition with increased TSH and low T4 levels?
What is the probable diagnosis for a girl who has experienced continuous urinary dribbling and persistent bladder fullness since birth?
questions.explanation:
Ectopic ureter

Etiology
  • It results from abnormal embryological development, often associated with ureteral duplication.

Pathology
  • Ectopic ureters drain to sites other than the bladder, which is commonly associated with duplication of the ureter.

Pathophysiology

  • In females, ectopic ureters open below the urethral sphincter or into the vagina, leading to incontinence.

  • In males, ectopic ureters usually open above the external urethral sphincter, maintaining continence.

Types

  • Bilateral ectopic ureters (10% of cases).

  • Unilateral ectopic ureters.

Clinical Features

 

  • Females: Continuous urinary incontinence despite normal voiding.

  • Males: Typically asymptomatic or continent due to ureter opening above the sphincter.

Diagnosis

  • Computed Tomo-Urography (CTU).

  • Magnetic Resonance Urography (MRU).

Lab Investigations
  • Primarily imaging-based diagnostics (CTU or MRU).

Complications

  • Persistent incontinence in females.

  • Potential recurrent urinary tract infections.

Differential Diagnosis

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux

  • Urethral Stricture: Difficulty in urination and weak stream, not continuous incontinence.

  • Neurogenic Bladder

Treatment
  • Surgical correction: Reposition it into the bladder to restore normal continence.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents with multiple oral and genital ulcers. The patient claims these ulcers resolve spontaneously and that she experiences such episodes at least four times a year. Ocular examination reveals features of anterior uveitis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Behcet’s Disease- Pathogenesis and Clinical Features

Category

Features

Clinical Significance

Pathogenesis
  • T-cell mediated immunity
  • Th1 cell activation
  • Elevated cytokines (IL-1, TNF-α)
  • Neutrophilic vasculitis
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • Auto-inflammatory rather than autoimmune
  • Affects vessels of all sizes
  • Treatment targets inflammation

Mucocutaneous
  • Oral ulcers (97-99%)
  • Genital ulcers (>80%)
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Pathergy reaction
  • Often initial presentation
  • Oral ulcers heal without scarring
  • Genital ulcers leave scars

Major Organ Involvement
  • Uveitis (>50%)
  • Vascular (25%)
  • Neurologic (5-10%)
  • Arthritis (non-erosive)
  • More severe in males
  • Ocular disease can cause blindness
  • Vascular involvement can be fatal

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who visits the clinic with complaints of frequent falls and walking difficulties. She also has a history of smoking and type-1 diabetes but no history of hypertension or coronary artery disease. During examination, the patient exhibits weakness in both lower limbs, absent DTR, as well as an unsteady gait. But, there is a decrease in proprioception and vibration sense in both lower limbs. Which of the following statements is correct about the above condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the dorsal column is involved

options.label: B
options.text: All these patients with a neurological impairment will show macrocytosis

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin B12 supplements do not improve this condition

options.label: D
options.text: Copper deficiency may produce similar symptoms

questions.correct_answer: D. Copper deficiency may produce similar symptoms
questions.explanation:
Subacute combined degeneration

Description
  • Reversible myelopathy mainly involving Dorsal column and Pyramidal column tracts

Etiology
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Nutritional (vegetarians) Pernicious anemia, post-gastrectomy, Diphyllobothrium infection

Clinical features
  • Weakness: Corticospinal tract (CST)/Pyramidal tract involvement
  • Loss of vibration and proprioception: Dorsal column tract involvement
  • Ataxia: Romberg sign positive
  • DTR: Absent (Peripheral neuropathy), Babinski sign: Positive (CST involvement)
  • Dementia: reversible with therapy
  • Hyperpigmentation of interphalangeal joints

Investigations
  • Vitamin B12 assay: Methyl malonate/Homocysteine levels estimation
  • Peripheral blood smear: may reveal macrocytosis with hypersegmented neutrophils

 

  • NOTE: SACD can occur without macrocytosis as well

Management
  • Vitamin B12 supplements

Differential diagnosis
  • Hypocupric myelopathy: Serum Cu2+ levels should be checked

questions.text: For hairy cell leukemia, which drug is considered the preferred choice?
questions.explanation:
Hairy cell leukemia

Mutations

BRAF V600E

Pathogenesis

Mutation of BRAF V600E gene → Activation of the BRAF protein → MAPK/ERK signalling pathway → Uncontrolled proliferation and survival of mature B-cells (Hairy cells).

Clinical Presentation

Presents with fatigue, recurrent infections, easy bruising, and symptoms related to splenomegaly (e.g., early satiety, abdominal discomfort), pancytopenia

Peripheral Blood Findings
  • Hairy cells with round, oblong, or reniform nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm.

Bone Marrow Biopsy Findings
  • Hypocellular or fibrotic marrow with "hairy cells".
  • Fried egg appearance.

Diagnosis
  • Flow cytometry
  • Immunophenotyping
  • Genetic testing for BRAF V600E mutation

Treatment
  • Splenectomy: Often leads to prolonged remission.
  • Nucleosides (Cladribine, Deoxycoformycin): Highly effective but cause immunosuppression;
  • Interferon-α (Option D): Effective but less so than nucleosides.
  • Vemurafenib (Option B) (BRAF inhibitor): Used in chemotherapy-refractory cases; not curative but maintains response with chronic use.
  • Vemurafenib + Rituximab (Option A): Leads to more durable remissions.

Prognosis

Excellent

questions.text: What could be the potential diagnosis for a 22-year-old male patient presenting with a history of accident, exhibiting leg abduction and external rotation?
questions.correct_answer: A. Anterior dislocation of the hip
questions.explanation:
Anterior hip dislocation

Classification
  • Type I: Pubic (superior) injuries
  • Type II: Obturator (inferior) injuries

Management
  • Reduction should be performed as soon as possible under sedation or general anesthesia.
  • Closed reduction technique:
    • Hold the affected leg in external rotation, abduction, and flexion.
    • Apply longitudinal traction.
    • Internally and externally rotate the leg until reduction is achieved, and apply anterior pressure on the femoral head if necessary.
    • If repeated attempts fail, consider an open reduction.

Complications
  • Injury to the sciatic nerve.
  • Avascular necrosis of the femoral head: may require hip replacement if osteoarthritis develops.

 

 

  •   Osteoarthritis: develops years later. Treatment varies from conservative to total hip replacement.

 

  • Myositis Ossificans: Develops weeks to months post-injury and is characterized by pain and stiffness. Ill-advised vigorous and improper massage following trauma is the most common cause.Treatment includes rest and analgesics.

 

  • Potential for associated femoral head fractures.

Posterior dislocation of hip (Option B ruled out)

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central fracture-dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:

  • Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

  • Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

  • The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.

questions.text: What is the most specific test used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Carpal tunnel syndrome

Definition

Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist

Symptoms
  • Numbness, tingling in thumb, index, and middle fingers
  • Pain in hand and wrist
  • Weakness in grip
  • Symptoms often worse at night and improve during the day.
  • Advanced cases may lead to constant symptoms, hand weakness, clumsiness, and muscle atrophy.

Structures Affected
  • Median Nerve: Compressed within the carpal tunnel, leading to symptoms and signs.
  • Flexor Tendons: The nine flexor tendons passing through the carpal tunnel can become inflamed, further compressing the median nerve.

Structures Spared
  • Thenar Eminence: Sensory loss generally spares this area because its nerve (palmar sensory cutaneous nerve) bypasses the carpal tunnel.

Clinical Signs
  • Weakness: Notable weakness in thumb abduction and opposition.
  • Atrophy: Possible atrophy of the thenar eminence in advanced cases.
  • Sensory Loss: Loss typically affects the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the fourth digit).

Causes
  • Idiopathic- commonest cause
  • Inflammatory causes- Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis
  • Post-traumatic causes- Bone thickening after a Colles' fracture
  • Endocrine causes- Myxoedema, Acromegaly

Diagnostic Tests
  • Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) - primary diagnostic test
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Carpal Compression Test/ Durkan test: Diagnostic test. Positive if pain/paresthesias occur during pressure application over the carpal tunnel.
  • Phalen Test: Positive if pain/paresthesias arise during wrist flexion. (Option B ruled out)
  • Tinel Test: Positive if tapping over the carpal tunnel elicits symptoms. (Option C ruled out)

Treatment
  • Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification
  • Corticosteroid injections
  • Surgical: Carpal tunnel release (for severe or refractory cases)

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of a patient admitted in the medicine ward with a fever. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Leptospirosis

Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria)

Reservoir
  • Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals

Source
  • Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals.
  • Exposure to flooded rice paddies.

At risk individuals
  • Males 20-45 years (most common)
  • Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water
    • Sports: rafting, fishing and swimming
    • Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers

Mode of transmission
  • Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion
  • Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation
  • Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows.

Incubation
  • 4-20 days

Diagnosis
  • Clinical features: High fever, severe headache, muscle pain, conjunctival suffusion, and jaundice
  • Dark Field examination: Thin and motile spirochete.
  • IgM ELISA: High sensitivity
  • Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, thrombocytopenia

Treatment
  • DOC: Penicillin 6 million units daily.
  • Alternate drugs:
    • Doxycycline
    • Amoxicillin
    • Ampicillin
    • Ceftriaxone

Prevention
  • Avoid contaminated water and use protective clothing
  • Livestock vaccination, proper waste disposal
  • Rodent control measures: Zinc phosphide

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is least injured during thyroid surgery?
questions.explanation:
Complications of Thyroidectomy

Hemorrhage
  • Bleeding from muscular arteries or slippage of ligature from superior thyroid vessels.
  • Complication: Tension hematoma causing respiratory distress. Management: Immediate re-operation, open sutures, control bleeding, drain hematoma, and close the wound.

Respiratory Obstruction
  • Primary Cause: Laryngeal edema from extubation injury. (Most Common Complication)
  • Other Causes: RLN palsy and tension hematoma.

Nerve Injury
  • Commonly Injured Nerve: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.
  • Other Injuries: RLN Injury causing palsy and Cervical sympathetic trunk causing Horner's syndrome. (Options A & B ruled out)

Parathyroid Insufficiency
  • Ligating the inferior thyroid artery away from the thyroid leads to parathyroid vascular infarction.
  • Causes hypocalcemia (low calcium levels) presenting 2–5 days post-surgery.

Thyroid Insufficiency

Total thyroidectomy leads to hypothyroidism and requires lifelong levothyroxine replacement.

Thyrotoxic Crisis

Inadequate preoperative preparation in hyperthyroid patients leads to the release of thyroid hormones during surgery.

questions.text: A counterforce brace is used in?
questions.explanation:
Lateral epicondylitis (Tennis elbow)

Definition

A condition characterized by pain and tenderness at the lateral epicondyle of the humerus due to non-specific inflammation at the origin of the extensor muscles of the forearm

Causes
  • Overuse of extensor muscles
  • Repetitive activities (e.g., tennis, typing, using mouse)
  • Non-specific inflammation at muscle origin

Clinical Features
  • Pain and tenderness precisely localized to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain aggravated by extending the wrist against resistance
  • Normal X-ray findings

Tests
  • Cozen's test: Also known as the resisted wrist extension test or resistive tennis elbow test, this test involves the patient making a fist and resisting wrist extension while the examiner applies pressure. The test is positive if the patient experiences pain on the lateral epicondyle.
  • Maudsley's test: This test involves the patient pronating their forearm and resisting extension of the third digit of their hand while the examiner stabilizes the humerus. The test is positive if the patient experiences sudden pain on the lateral epicondyle.
  • Mills's test: Another common test for tennis elbow.

Treatment
  • Initial: Analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs
  • If no response: Local injection of hydrocortisone at the point of maximum tenderness
  • Physical therapy and activity modification

questions.text: The brace shown in the given image is:

A 55-year-old man with IHD presents with sudden, severe, generalised abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118 bpm, rhythm is irregularly irregular, and BP is 90/60 mmHg. The abdomen appears soft and non-distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following could be a likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Acute mesenteric ischemia

Aspects

Description

Definition
  • Sudden reduction in blood supply to the intestines, leading to ischemia and potential necrosis.
  • Commonly involves the Superior mesenteric artery (SMA).

Clinical Features
  • Pain: Severe, sudden-onset abdominal pain disproportionate to physical findings.
  • Others: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bloody stools, shock.

Risk Factors
  • Cardiovascular: Atrial fibrillation, recent MI, heart failure.
  • Vascular: Atherosclerosis, vasculitis.
  • Others: Hypercoagulable states.

Radiological Features

CT Angiography: Preferred diagnostic tool; reveals SMA occlusion, String of sausage sign, bowel wall thickening, pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas.

Management
  • Initial: IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, pain control.
  • Definitive: Anticoagulation (e.g., IV heparin), surgical embolectomy, bowel resection. Vasodilators (e.g., papaverine) can be used intra-arterially to relieve vasospasm.

questions.text: To which part of the vertebra are the screws fixed in spine fusion surgery?
Which of the following is false about Mycoplasma pneumoniae?

options.label: D
options.text: Can be cultured in a cell-free medium

questions.explanation:
Atypical Pneumonia (Walking Pneumonia)

Definition

Atypical pneumonia is a milder form of pneumonia, often caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, certain viruses, or moulds.

Symptoms
  • Cough, fever, chest pain, headache, and chills, resembling a bad cold.
  • As it is generally mild, not requiring bed rest or hospitalization, allowing people to continue daily activities called"walking pneumonia."

Etiologic Agents
  • Atypical pneumonia is caused by organisms that don't grow on standard cultures or appear on Gram stain, such as:
    • Mycoplasma pneumonia (associated with closed living conditions like at school and military barracks)
    • Chlamydia pneumoniae
    • Legionella species (from stagnant water sources or from air conditioners)
    • Respiratory viruses: Influenza, adenoviruses, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), human metapneumoviruses, and coronaviruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2)

Prevalence
  • Cases of atypical pneumonia are increasing, particularly among young adults.

Diagnosis
  • These pathogens cannot be cultured in the usual ways, making diagnosis more complex.
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a unique bacterium that lacks a cell wall and requires a specialized cell-free medium for culture (Option D) as it cannot be grown on conventional culture media.
  • Detection of specific antibodies (Option B) (IgM and IgG) against Mycoplasma pneumoniae, can be helpful in confirming the diagnosis.
  • PCR and other molecular methods are often necessary for confirmation.

Radiology

  • Chest X-ray findings in Mycoplasma pneumonia can vary, but bilateral infiltrates (Option C) are commonly seen. Infiltrates may appear as patchy or diffuse opacities in both lungs. However, chest X-ray findings alone cannot definitively diagnose Mycoplasma pneumonia and should be correlated with clinical symptoms and other diagnostic tests.

Treatment
  • The absence of a cell wall makes these organisms resistant to certain antibiotics that target cell wall synthesis, such as penicillins and cephalosporins and require treatment with macrolides like azithromycin, and fluoroquinolones, or tetracyclines like doxycycline.

questions.explanation:
Blunt Force Injuries

Sharp Force Injuries
  • Abrasion: Superficial damage to the skin (scraping, rubbing off the outer layer).
  • Contusion: Bruise caused by blood vessels rupturing under the skin due to impact.
  • Laceration: Irregular tear in the skin or tissue caused by crushing or blunt trauma.
  • Fractures/Dislocations: Breaks or misalignment of bones due to strong blunt impact.
  • Incision: A clean-cut wound where the length is greater than the depth.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the management of snakebite in India?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: ASV is the mainstay of treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Current ASV in India is not effective against humped pit viper

questions.correct_answer: A. Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite
questions.explanation:
First Aid: ‘ CARRY NO RIGHT ’

CARRY
  • Do not allow the victim to walk on their own, must be carried (in any form) to the hospital as soon as possible.

NO
  • No Suction
  • No Cautery
  • No Ligature
  • No Tourniquet

RIGHT
  • R: Reassure the patient
  • I: Immobilize the limb: by application of crepe bandages (Sutherland wraps)
  • GH: Get to the Hospital immediately
  • T: Tell history/symptoms

Pressure bandage
  • Used for immobilization of the limb by application of crepe bandage - known as Sutherland wraps.
  • Contraindicated in viper bites.
  • Ideal pressure: 50-70 mm Hg.

ASV
  • Mainstay of treatment.
  • Used only when signs of systemic poisoning are present
  • Polyvalent anti snake venom (PAV) used in India can neutralize (i) Cobra (ii) Krait (iii) Russel viper (iv) Saw-scaled viper bites.
  • Dose: 1-2 ml/kg (!0 vials) irrespective of sex/age.
  • Each vial: neutralizes 6-8 mg of snake venom
  • Test dose is not required/advised to be given before initiating ASV.
  • Ideally to be given within 4 hours of snake bite.
  • To be given until clinical improvement (in cobra bites)/ Clotting time becomes normal (in viper bites).

Adjuvant treatment
  • Neostigmine 1.5mg: for neuroparalytic symptoms (cobra bite).
  • Atropine 0.5mg: To antagonize muscarinic actions of Ach.
  • Surgical debridement and FFP may be required in Viper bites.

questions.explanation:
Chop wounds/ Slash wounds

  • These are deep gaping wounds inflicted by a blow with the moderately sharp cutting edge of a heavy weapon when applied with significant force.
  • It is a combination of blunt and sharp force injury.

Weapons used

  • Hatchet
  • Axe
  • Sword
  • Broad heavy knife
  • Chopper
  • Saber
  • Meat cleaver

Features of the wound
  • The axe's lower end (heel) strikes first, leaving a deeper wound than the upper end (toe).
  • It is an incised wound on skin with an underlying communited fracture or deep grove in the bone.
  • Dimensions of the wound correspond to the cross-section of the penetrating blade.
  • Margins are sharp and may have abrasions, bruising, and some lacerations with severe injury to underlying organs.

Medicolegal importance

  • Most injuries are homicidal.
  • Frew are accidental by machinery (propeller injuries).
  • Rarely suicidal.
  • Wounds give details of the weapon used and the direction of attack.

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in casualty when an MLC (Medico-Legal Case) is brought by the police. The deceased has the following appearance and was declared brought dead. What is the likely cause of death before sending the body for postmortem?

Seawater drowning

Cause of death

Ventricular fibrillation

Cardiac arrest due to fulminant pulmonary edema.

Changes in blood

Hemodilution, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypochloremia

Hemoconcentration, hypernatremia, hypovolemia, hypochloremia.

Lungs

Pinkish in colour, emphysematous, crepitus is heard

Purplish or bluish colour, soft in consistency, no crepitus is heard.

Copious fluid and froth are seen.

Fatal period

4-5 minutes

8-12 minutes

Types of atypical drowning

Dry drowning

  • In dry drowning, water does not enter the lungs due to laryngeal spasms induced by small amounts of water entering the larynx.
  • Cause of death: Reflex cardiac arrest due to vasovagal stimulation.

Immersion syndrome (Cold water drowning)
  • It refers to syncope resulting from cardiac arrhythmias on sudden
  • contact with water that is at least 5°C lower than the body temperature.
  • Also called hydrocution or submersion inhibition.

Near drowning (post-immersion syndrome or secondary drowning)
  • Near drowning refers to survival beyond 24 hours after a submersion episode.
  • Death is caused by complications or sequelae like ARDS, pneumonia, sepsis, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, and DIC.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man was found dead at home and brought to the mortuary by the police. Upon examination, certain findings were noted. What is the likely cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Face
  • Congested, swollen, and cyanosed.
  • Tardieu's spots (petechiae) on the forehead, temples, eyelids, and conjunctiva.
  • Prominent eyes with congested conjunctiva, dilated pupils, and possible subconjunctival haemorrhages.
  • Cyanosis of lips, fingernails, and earlobes.
  • Postmortem staining above the ligature.
  • Swollen, dark-coloured, protruding tongue, possibly bitten.
  • Bloodstained frothy fluid and mucus in mouth and nostrils.

Neck
  • Ligature mark ('furrow'): well-defined groove, typically the same width as the ligature, often horizontal.
  • More prominent on the front and sides of the neck.
  • Red base with congested or ecchymosed margins; imprint pattern may be present.
  • Can be indistinct if the ligature is soft; it may appear as a deep groove with a narrow cord ('cheese cutter method').
  • May show an oblique appearance if the victim was dragged post-strangulation.

Other Body Parts
  • Deep, prominent postmortem staining.
  • Involuntary discharge of urine and faecal matter; less common seminal ejaculation.
  • Clenched hands; possible genital turgidity.
  • Possible abrasions, fingernail marks, and contusions on face, and arms, indicating struggle.
  • Horizontal, irregular abrasions on the neck may indicate attempts to remove ligature.

Features

Hanging

Strangulation by ligature

Face

  • Usually, pale and petechiae are absent.
  • Swelling and protrusion of the tongue is less.
  • Saliva dripping is seen.
  • Bleeding from the nose, mouth and ears are absent.
  • Congested, livid and marked with petechiae.
  • Swelling and protrusion of the tongue are more marked.
  • Saliva is absent.
  • Bleeding from the nose, mouth and ears is commonly seen.

Ligature mark
  • It is oblique and does not completely encircle the neck.
  • It is usually seen high up in the neck between the chin and larynx.
  • The base is hard and pale.
  • It is transverse, completely encircling the neck.
  • It is seen below the thyroid cartilage.
  • The base is soft and reddish.

Abrasions and ecchymoses
  • At the edges of the ligature marks are rare.
  • At the edges of the ligature marks are common.

Subcutaneous tissue and neck muscles
  • The subcutaneous tissue is white, hard and glistening under the mark.
  • Bruising of the neck muscles is rare.
  • The subcutaneous tissue shows severe engorgement and haemorrhage into tissues in and above the area compressed.
  • Bruising of the neck muscles is more common.

Bone and cartilage involvement
  • Fracture of the hyoid bone may occur.
  • Fracture of the thyroid cartilage, larynx and trachea is more common.

Lungs

  • No bullae are seen on the surface of the lungs.
  • Emphysematous bullae are commonly seen on the surface of the lungs.

Carotid artery
  • Damage may be seen.
  • Damage is rare.

Involuntary discharge
  • Faeces and urine are less common.
  • Seminal discharge is more common.
  • Faeces and urine are more common.
  • Seminal discharge is rare.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with complaints of increasing fatigue and shortness of breath. Upon auscultation, the physician detects a pan systolic murmur that is best heard at the right side of the heart. The murmur radiates to the axilla and is louder during inspiration. The patient denies any history of fever, chest pain, or recent infections. What is the most probable diagnosis for this patient's condition based on the described findings?
questions.explanation:
Aortic Stenosis (Option A) Systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern, radiating to carotids, best heard at the right upper sternal border
Mitral Valve Prolapse (Option B) Late systolic murmur is best heard at the apex, not a pan systolic murmur. Typically preceded by a non-ejection click, and intensity and duration increases with maneuvers that decrease ventricular volume.
Ventricular Septal Defect (Option C) Harsh, holosystolic murmur heard, best at the left lower sternal border, as blood flows from the higher-pressure left ventricle to the lower-pressure right ventricle.

questions.text: Correct sequence after p wave: A - ‘a’ wave B - 1 st heart sound C - Rapid filling of ventricles D - ‘t’ wave
questions.explanation:
a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole.
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria.
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

questions.text: The given condition is caused by which drug ?
questions.explanation:
Side Effect

Description

Pulmonary Toxicity

Bleomycin is known to cause lung damage, which can lead to pulmonary fibrosis and respiratory symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, and decreased lung function.

Skin Toxicity

Bleomycin can cause skin reactions, including flagellate dermatitis (linear streaks on the skin), erythema (redness), and skin desquamation (peeling).

Mucosal Toxicity

Bleomycin can cause mucosal damage, resulting in mouth sores, sore throat, and inflammation of the oral and nasal mucosa.

Fever

Fever is a common side effect of Bleomycin treatment and can occur shortly after administration.

Hematologic Toxicity

Bleomycin can suppress bone marrow function, leading to decreased production of blood cells, including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.

Nail Changes

Bleomycin can cause nail abnormalities, including nail discoloration, brittle nails, and nail bed inflammation.

Allergic Reactions

Allergic reactions to Bleomycin can occur, ranging from mild rash to severe hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis.

Foramen Lacerum

A triangular opening at the base of the skull, but in living individuals, it is filled with cartilage, and no major structures pass through it.

  • Foramen lacerum contributed by 3 bones-temporal, occipital and sphenoid

  • The internal carotid artery and nerve plexus traverse its superior end;

  • The nerve to the pterygoid canal passes through its anterior wall.

  • The meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery and an emissary vein pass through it.

What is the most probable diagnosis for a young girl who experiences constant urine dribbling, despite voiding normally, and has never been completely dry since birth, according to her parents?
questions.explanation:
Etiology
  • Results from abnormal embryological development, often associated with ureteral duplication.

Pathology
  • Ectopic ureters drain to sites other than the bladder, commonly associated with duplication of the ureter.

Pathophysiology
  • Females, ectopic ureters open below the urethral sphincter or into the vagina, leading to incontinence.
  • Males, ectopic ureters usually open above the external urethral sphincter, maintaining continence.

Types
  • Bilateral ectopic ureters (10% of cases).
  • Unilateral ectopic ureters.

Clinical Features
  • Females: Continuous urinary incontinence despite normal voiding.
  • Males: Typically asymptomatic or continent due to ureter opening above the sphincter.

Diagnosis
  • Computed Tomo-Urography (CTU).
  • Magnetic Resonance Urography (MRU).

Laboratory Investigations
  • Primarily imaging-based diagnostics (CTU or MRU).

Complications
  • Persistent incontinence in females.
  • Potential recurrent urinary tract infections.

Differential Diagnosis
  • Vesicoureteral Reflux
  • Urethral Stricture : Difficulty in urination and weak stream, not continuous incontinence.
  • Neurogenic Bladder :

Treatment
  • Surgical correction: Reposition it into the bladder to restore normal continence.

Which of the following should be administered in addition to airway management for a 3-year-old child experiencing symptoms such as rapid breathing, high fever, noisy breathing during inhalation, and difficulty swallowing with excessive saliva production within 4-6 hours of the onset of fever?
questions.explanation:
Causative Agent

  • Past Era (Pre-vaccine): Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)

  • Post-vaccine Era:

    • Streptococcus pneumoniae (M/c), Streptococcus pyogenes, non-typeable H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus

    • Hib cases have decreased by 99% due to widespread vaccination.

Clinical Features

  • Child appears toxic with high fever, rapid breathing.

  • Difficulty swallowing with excessive saliva production (drooling).

  • Neck hyperextension to maintain airway, Tripod position (sitting upright, leaning forward)

  • Stridor (noisy breathing during inhalation) is a late sign indicating near-complete airway obstruction.

  • Cyanosis, Coma.

Diagnosis

  • Laryngoscopy: Large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis

 

  • Lateral neck X-ray: Thumb sign

Treatment

  • Immediate Treatment:

    • Secure airway.

    • Intubation decreases mortality from 6% to <1% in epiglottitis cases.

    • Culture Collection: Blood, epiglottic surface and CSF in certain cases after the airway is stabilized.

  • Antibiotics: Ceftriaxone, cefepime or meropenem given parenterally for 10 days.

Recovery

Symptoms improve with a few days of antibiotics, and the patient may be extubated.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a probability distribution that represents the likelihood of a specific number of events occurring within a specific time period?
When would you choose to utilize a sanitizer? Prior to conducting a patient examination Following a patient examination After coming into contact with the patient's environment On open wound
questions.explanation:
Alcohol-Based Hand Sanitizers

Effectiveness of Alcohol-Based Hand Sanitizers

  • Contains ethanol, isopropanol, or a mix
  • Effectiveness depends on alcohol type, concentration (60-95%), application technique, and consistency.
  • Ethanol is more effective against viruses, while propanol is better for bacteria.

WHO Definition and Composition
  • Hand sanitizers consist of alcohol (liquid, gel, or foam), excipients, humectants, and sometimes antimicrobial agents (e.g., chlorhexidine for prolonged protection).
  • Higher alcohol concentrations (above recommended levels) can be paradoxically less effective due to reduced protein denaturation.

Indications and Limitations
  • Effective against most bacteria, fungi, and enveloped viruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2, Ebola, Zika).
  • Less effective against protozoan oocysts, non-enveloped viruses (e.g., norovirus, poliovirus), and bacterial spores (e.g., Clostridioides difficile).
  • Ineffective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with certain pathogens.

Contraindications and Risks
  • Can cause skin reactions like dryness, irritation, contact dermatitis, and rarely urticaria.
  • Frequent use may lead to minor alcohol absorption, though considered safe.
  • Fire hazard due to flammability

WHO-Recommended Formulations
  • Ethanol-based (80%) - Ethanol, glycerol, hydrogen peroxide, distilled water.
  • Isopropyl alcohol-based (75%) - Isopropyl alcohol, glycerol, hydrogen peroxide, distilled water.

Proper Application Technique
  • Apply 2.4 mL sanitizer, rub thoroughly for 15-30 seconds until dry.
  • Some dispensers may not release adequate amounts; users should ensure sufficient application.

questions.text: Which of the following can be considered effective CPR? 1. Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute 2. Chest compressions: 100-120/min 3. Allow complete chest recoil 4. 5-6cm deep compression
questions.explanation:
Compressions (C)

Position: Place the patient in a supine position on a firm surface.

Site: Lower ⅓ rd of sternum

Rate: 100 to 120 compressions per minute. (Statement 2)

Depth: Compress 2 to 2.4 inches (5-6 cm); avoid exceeding 2.4 inches. (Statement 4)

Compression-to-Ventilation Ratio: 30 compressions to 2 breaths (30:2). (Statement 1)

Chest Recoil: Allow full recoil between compressions to optimize blood flow. (Statement 3)

Interruptions: Minimize interruptions in compressions (<10 seconds).

Chest Compression Fraction (CCF): The proportion of time spent performing chest compressions during CPR: Maintain a CCF ≥ 60%.

For pregnant women: perform manual lateral uterine displacement (LUD) to relieve pressure on large abdominal vessels.

Airway (A)

Head Tilt-Chin Lift: Used to open the airway in patients without suspected neck trauma.

Jaw Thrust: Preferred method, if neck trauma is suspected.

The most common cause of airway obstruction in unconscious patients is the tongue falling back.

Breathing (B)

Rescue Breaths: Give 2 breaths after every 30 compressions.

Method: Mouth-to-mouth or with a bag-mask device, ensuring chest rise with each breath.

Breath Duration: Each breath should last about 1 second.

options.text: Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

questions.correct_answer: D. Poor prognosis compared to classical HL
questions.explanation:
Subtype

Morphology and Immunophenotype

Typical Clinical Features

Nodular Sclerosis
  • Frequent lacunar cells and occasional diagnostic Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells.
  • Background infiltrate includes T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells.
  • Fibrous bands divide cellular areas into nodules.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+; usually EBV negative.
  • Most common subtype, typically stage I or II with mediastinal involvement.
  • Equal occurrence in males and females.
  • Common in young adults.

Mixed Cellularity
  • Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells.
  • Background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+; 70% EBV positive.
  • More than 50% present as stage III or IV.
  • More common in males.
  • Biphasic incidence peaks in young adults and those >55 years.

Lymphocyte-Rich
  • Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells. Background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+; 40% EBV positive.
  • Uncommon, more frequent in males.
  • Typically seen in older adults.

Lymphocyte Depletion
  • Reticular variant with numerous RS cells and few background reactive cells.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+, most EBV positive.
  • Rare, more common in older men, HIV-infected individuals, and low-income regions.
  • Often presents with advanced disease.

Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant
  • Frequent L&H (popcorn) cell variants in a background of follicular dendritic cells and reactive B cells.
  • RS cells: CD20+, CD15−, CD30−; EBV negative.
  • Uncommon, typically in young males.
  • Presents with cervical/axillary lymphadenopathy.
  • Rarely involves the mediastinum.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image.
questions.explanation:
Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides)

Habitat

Adult worms reside in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum) and are the largest nematode parasites in humans.

Morphology

Adult Worms: Large, cylindrical, with tapering ends and pale pink color that turns white outside the body.

Male Worms:

  • Smaller than females (15-30 cm long, 2-4 mm thick)
  • A ventrally curved posterior end and two copulatory spicules.

Female Worms:

  • Larger than males
  • Straight, conical posterior end & a vulvar groove aiding in mating.

Reproduction

A single female can lay up to 200,000 eggs daily, which are expelled in the feces.

Host

Humans only

Infective Form

Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.

Transmission

Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water.

Life Cycle of Ascaris
  • Host: Humans only.
  • Infective Form: Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.
  • Transmission: Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water.

Life Cycle Phases

Migratory Phase
  • L2 larvae hatch, molt to L3, penetrate the intestine and travel to the lungs via the heart.
  • In the lungs, they molt to L4, migrate to the pharynx, and are swallowed back into the intestine.

Intestinal Phase
  • L4 larvae become adult worms in the small intestine.
  • Females lay fertilized eggs in feces; unfertilized eggs may also be laid.

Development in Soil
  • Fertilized eggs become infective embryonated (L2 larvae) in 2 weeks under suitable conditions.
  • Unfertilized eggs disintegrate and are non-infective.
  • Embryonated eggs can survive for up to 15 years due to a thick eggshell and ascaroside, a resistant lipoprotein.

Pathogenesis and Clinical Features
  • Caused by the host immune response, larval migration, adult worm obstruction, and nutritional deficiencies.
  • Incubation: 60–70 days.

Pulmonary Phase
  • Symptoms appear within two weeks post-ingestion: cough, chest discomfort, and fever.
  • Severe cases may lead to Loeffler’s syndrome, characterized by eosinophilic pneumonia and transient lung infiltrates.

Intestinal Phase
  • Most infections are asymptomatic, but malnutrition and growth retardation can occur, particularly in children <5 years.
  • Complications include intestinal obstruction, perforation, intussusception, or volvulus in older children.

Extraintestinal Complications
  • Larger worms may obstruct the biliary tree, causing biliary colic or pancreatitis.

Allergic Reactions
  • Reactions such as fever, urticaria, angioedema, and conjunctivitis may arise due to toxins released by adult worms.

Laboratory diagnosis & Treatment of Ascaris lumbricoides

Stool Examination
  • Detects both fertilized & unfertilized eggs using saline and iodine wet mount.
  • If negative, concentration by sedimentation is recommended (floatation is ineffective as unfertilized eggs do not float).

Adult Worm Detection
  • Occasionally visible in stool or sputum. Barium X-ray may show worms in the intestine as "trolley car lines" if aligned in parallel.
  • Ultrasound or cholangiopancreatography helps detect worms in extraintestinal sites.

Larva Detection
  • During early pulmonary migration, larvae may appear in sputum or gastric aspirates before stool detection.

Serology
  • Antibody testing (e.g., ELISA) is sensitive but cannot distinguish recent from past infections and may cross-react with other helminths.

Molecular Methods
  • PCR can identify Ascaris in stool, and differentiate between Ascaris, Trichuris, and hookworm.
  • Real-time PCR quantifies parasite load.

Other Indicators
  • Eosinophilia is common in early lung stages.
  • Charcot-Leyden crystals may appear in sputum and stool.

Treatment
  • Albendazole: 400 mg as a single dose.
  • Mebendazole: 100 mg twice daily for 3 days or 500 mg as a single dose.

Unfertilized Egg

Fertilized Egg
  • It is Elliptical, narrow, & long
  • Size: 80 µm x 55 µm
  • Shell: Thin with an irregular albumin coating
  • Contents: Small, atrophied ovum with disorganized refractile granules
  • Does not Float in saturated salt solution.
  • Round or oval in shape.
  • Size: 60-75 µm x 40-45 µm
  • Color: Golden brown, bile-stained
  • Shell: Thick, smooth, translucent with three layers
    • Outer: Coarsely mammillated albuminous coat
    • Middle: Thick transparent layer
    • Inner: Lipoidal vitelline membrane
  • Decorticated Variant: Some eggs lack the outer mammillated coat.
  • Contents: Large unsegmented ovum with coarse lecithin granules, leaving clear areas at poles
  • Floats in saturated salt solution.

Fertilised egg

Unfertilised egg

options.label: C
options.text: Cells do not lyse in a hypotonic solution

questions.explanation:
Abnormality

Condition

Reason

Bite cells

G6PD deficiency
  • Oxidative stress leads to cross-linking of sulfhydryl groups in haemoglobin → Denaturation of haemoglobin → Heinz bodies.
  • RBCs with Heinz bodies pass through the spleen → Splenic macrophages try to pluck these Heinz bodies → Membrane loss → Bite cells.

Target cells

Thalassemia
  • ↓ Haemoglobin content in RBCs → ↓ RBC volume → Surface area relatively unchanged → ↑ Surface area to volume ratio→ Altered lipid composition → ↑ Formation of membrane protrusions→ ↑ Membrane instability → ↓ Hemoglobin accumulation in certain membrane areas → Central area with haemoglobin, clear zone, outer ring.
  • Uneven distribution of haemoglobin and lipids → Characteristic "bull's-eye" appearance of Target cells

Sickle-shaped RBC

Sickle Cell Anemia

Abnormal Hemoglobin (HbS) → HbS molecules polymerize under low oxygen → RBCs become rigid and assume a sickle shape.

 

 

Spherocytes

Hereditary Spherocytosis

Genetic defect in RBC membrane protein(spectrin) ⟶ Loss of membrane surface area ⟶ RBCs become spherical.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man, after being involved in a road traffic accident (RTA), was brought to the casualty 6 hours later. His B.P. was 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, and SpO2 was 92%. A blood transfusion was administered. A few hours later, the patient becomes febrile and tachypneic and starts bleeding from the IV and NG tube sites. His SpO2 levels begin to drop. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Types of Transfusion reactions

Aspect

Immediate Transfusion Reactions

Delayed Transfusion Reactions

Onset

Within hours of transfusion

Days to weeks after transfusion

Cause

Immunologic reactions, hemolytic or non-hemolytic

Immune-mediated, often involving minor antigen sensitization

Presentation

Fever, chills, dyspnea (TRALI, TACO), Acute respiratory distress (TRALI), Pulmonary oedema (TACO), hypothermia, electrolyte abnormalities, coagulopathy, acid-base disorders and hyperkalemia.

Fever, jaundice, gradual decline in haemoglobin levels (hemolysis).

 

Severity

Can range from mild to life-threatening.

Generally less severe than immediate reactions.

Examples
  • Febrile non-hemolytic reaction (FNHTR)
  • Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)
  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Delayed hemolytic reaction

Management
  • Stop transfusion and manage symptoms.
  • Supportive care (e.g., antipyretics, oxygen).
  • Monitor for worsening anaemia and hemolysis.
  • Consider further transfusion support if indicated.

questions.explanation:
Apoptosis in physiological conditions 

Apoptosis in pathological conditions

1. The removal of supernumerary cells (in excess of the required number) during development.

2. Involution of hormone-dependent tissues on hormone withdrawal, such as endometrial cell breakdown during the menstrual cycle.

3. Elimination of potentially harmful self-reactive lymphocytes to prevent immune reactions against one’s own tissues.

4. Death of host cells that have served their useful purpose, such as neutrophils in an acute inflammatory response and lymphocytes at the end of an immune response.

1. DNA damage.

2. Accumulation of misfolded proteins

3. Apoptosis can be induced during infections such as adenovirus, HIV, and viral hepatitis.

4. It may also contribute to pathologic atrophy in parenchymal organs after duct obstruction, such as occurs in the pancreas, parotid gland, and kidney

Affinity maturation is due to:
questions.explanation:
Stage

Process

Key Components

Initial B Cell Activation

1. Antigen Recognition:

  • B cell captures antigen via surface IgM/IgD
  • Antigen internalization

2. Antigen Processing:

  • Processed into peptides
  • Loaded onto MHC-II molecules
  • B cell receptor (BCR) (IgM and IgD)
  • Surface immunoglobulins
  • MHC-II molecules

B Cell-T Cell Interaction

1. Signal Generation:

  • Signal 1: Antigen presentation to TH cells
  • Signal 2: CD40-CD40L interaction
  • Signal 3: Cytokine stimulation

2. T Cell Help:

  • TH1: IFN-γ (IgG production)
  • TH2: IL-4 (IgE production)
  • TCR-MHC-II complex
  • CD40-CD40L
  • Cytokine receptors
  • Co-stimulatory molecules

B Cell Response

1. Germinal Center Formation:

  • B cell proliferation
  • Somatic hypermutation
  • Class switching

2. Differentiation:

  • • Into plasma cells
  • • Into memory B cells
  • Antibody production
  • Affinity maturation
  • Immunological memory

Outcomes

1. Immediate Response:

  • Antibody secretion
  • Different Ig classes based on cytokines

2. Long-term Response:

  • Memory formation
  • Enhanced secondary response
  • IgG, IgA, IgE production
  • High-affinity antibodies
  • Long-lived plasma cells
  • Memory B cells

questions.explanation:
Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

  • Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite) (Option A ruled out)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles. (Option B ruled out)
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

  • The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

questions.text: Identify the condenser in the given image.
questions.explanation:
Part of the Light Microscope

Function

Source of Illumination
  • Visible Light

Stage
  • Slides are placed on it

Condenser
  • Regulates the passage of light

Big Knob
  • Coarse adjustment

Small Knob
  • Fine adjustment

Eyepiece Lens
  • 10x magnification

Objective Lens
  • Scanner: 4x
  • Low Power: 10x
  • High Power: 40x
  • Oil Immersion: 100x

Magnification

Resolution

Contrast
  • Magnification describes the capacity to enlarge an image.
  • All microscopes employ lenses that improve magnification.
  • However, the limiting factor for distinguishing is not magnification.
  • Maximum magnification is 1000x.
  • Resolution is the ability to distinguish two adjacent objects as distinct and separate.
  • The limit of resolution for a light microscope is nearly 0.2 μm.
  • Two objects near less than 0.2 μm from each other cannot be resolved as distinct and separate.
  • Contrast is necessary to distinguish microorganisms from their surroundings.
  • Bright-field microscopy uses staining to visualise bacteria with a good contrasting effect.
  • Advances have been made in microscopy and new contrast methods, such as phase contrast, differential interference contrast, dark field, and fluorescence.

questions.text: What level of biosafety containment is required for specimen handling for molecular testing of SARS-CoV-2?
Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Application Example

Homogeneous ELISA

One-step procedure; no separation of bound and free fractions needed.

Suitable for analysing haptens like drugs.

Enzyme-multiplied immunoassay technique (EMIT) for drug detection

Heterogeneous ELISA

Multi-step process requiring separation of bound and free fractions (e.g., by centrifugation).

Commonly used for microbial antigen and antibody detection.

Standard ELISA

Method

Description

Example

Sandwich ELISA

Used to detect antigens by capturing them between two antibodies (capture and detection antibodies).

Detection of rotavirus antigen in faeces

Indirect ELISA

Used to detect antibodies in the sample.

Anti-HIV antibody test

Competitive ELISA

Antigen in the sample competes with known antigen for a limited amount of antibody; produces an inverse curve (less colour at higher antigen levels).

Hapten detection

Capture ELISA

Highly specific for detecting specific antigens.

Various immunometric tests

Modification

Description and Application

Example

Cylinder/Cassette ELISA

For rapid, small-scale testing using disposable cassettes.

Results are read visually without special equipment.

Dot Blot Assay for HIV detection

Sandwich ELISA

Used specifically for antigen detection.

Detection of food toxins and adulterants
